name: Multisystemic Therapy (MST)
summary: An intensive, evidence-based, home- and community-based treatment program for adolescents with serious behavioral, emotional, and criminal problems, focusing on the multiple systems that influence their development.
description: Multisystemic Therapy (MST) is a family- and community-based treatment designed for adolescents at risk of incarceration or out-of-home placement due to severe antisocial behavior, conduct problems, or substance use. Grounded in ecological and systems theory, MST addresses the many factors influencing a youth’s behavior, including family, peers, school, and neighborhood. The program empowers caregivers with the skills and resources to manage their child’s behavior, improve family functioning, reduce association with deviant peers, enhance school performance, and promote pro-social community involvement. MST is typically delivered in the home with intensive therapist involvement and 24/7 availability for crises.

contraindications: Severe psychosis or acute psychiatric crises requiring hospitalization
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and effective when delivered by trained practitioners; requires high family engagement.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High—numerous RCTs and meta-analyses confirm effectiveness; listed in SAMHSA’s National Registry of Evidence-based Programs and Practices.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Strong international evidence base; replicated across multiple countries and settings.

sections.text: MST uses ecological systems theory to address the multiple factors influencing adolescent behavior. Interventions target parenting practices, peer influences, school engagement, and community supports. Therapists work closely with caregivers to build skills and empower families, while reducing risk factors such as delinquent peer associations and reinforcing protective factors like positive social supports and school success.

sections.preparation: Initial assessment of youth and family risk factors, strengths, and systemic influences.
procedure: Frequent home-based therapy sessions (several times per week).
Integration of cognitive-behavioral techniques, family systems interventions, and skills training.
Collaboration with schools, juvenile justice, and community organizations.
sections.frequency: Multiple sessions per week depending on family needs.
sections.total_treatment_time: Intensive short-term model with high contact frequency.

sections.pre_session: Review of goals, recent behaviors, and caregiver feedback.
sections.treatment_phase: Skills training, systemic interventions, crisis response, and practice of new strategies.
sections.post_session: Homework assignments, progress monitoring, and coordination with community systems.

absolute: Immediate danger to self or others requiring inpatient care

ideal_candidates: Adolescents with chronic behavioral or delinquent problems
Families experiencing high conflict and instability
Youth at risk for incarceration or residential placement

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in MST model

studies: Henggeler, S. W. et al. (1998). Multisystemic treatment of antisocial behavior in children and adolescents.
Meta-analyses show MST reduces recidivism, substance use, and family conflict.
sections.limitations: Resource-intensive; requires high family engagement; not suitable for severe psychiatric disorders needing hospitalization.

sections.total_treatment_cost: $7,000–$12,000 per youth (varies by program and location)
sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered by Medicaid, juvenile justice, or child welfare systems
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective compared to incarceration or residential care

sections.children: Not typically used for young children.

items: MST is evidence-based and internationally recognized.
Therapists have low caseloads for high intensity.
Focuses on empowering caregivers as the long-term agents of change.

items.label: Henggeler, S. W. et al. (1998). Multisystemic Treatment of Antisocial Behavior in Children and Adolescents.
